channel.title: IndexOutOfBoundsException?

item.title: IndexOutOfBoundsException?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“sp11k3t3ht3rd, post:3, topic:427060”][quote author=imsuperman05 link=topic=529760.msg3867047#msg3867047 date=1325091291]
Use an iterator instead of a loop.
[/quote]

Don’t iterators get screwed up once you remove and add things to the array though?[/quote]

No, iterators throw a ConcurrentModificationException, letting the programmer know they are trying to modify something while iterating across it, which is exactly what you are doing. It’s by sheer chance your code happened to be setup to throw an exception in the first place, to let you know. Java collections are designed to stop bad behavior such as that. If you choose not to utilize this functionality, you need to be immensely careful when modifying arrays while reading them. You can get some very funky behavior when you concurrently modify a collection or array, and not always in a way that will crash your program.

Read full topic

item.title: IndexOutOfBoundsException?
item.dc:creator: @sp11k3t3ht3rd sp11k3t3ht3rd
item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

EDIT: Nvm.

Fixed with this:

[code=java5] if(j >= Player.numOfOre) {

            int oresRemoved = 0;
            
            System.out.println(Player.inventory);
            System.out.println(Player.inventory.size());

            for(int i = 0; i < Player.inventory.size(); i++) {
                
                if(Player.inventory.get(i).equals(Player.ore) && oresRemoved <= Player.numOfOre) {
                    
                    while (Player.inventory.get(i).equals(Player.ore) && oresRemoved < Player.numOfOre) {
                        
                        Player.inventory.remove(i);
                        oresRemoved++;
                            
                        if(Player.inventory.isEmpty()) {
                               
                            break;
                                
                        }
                        
                    }
                        
                }
                
            }[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: IndexOutOfBoundsException?
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

Your problem is the expression “Player.inventory.get(i)” in your while-loop.

You’re expecting the expression “Player.inventory.get(i).equals(Player.ore)” to return false, but a List will throw an IndexOutOfBoundsException if the index is out of range (index < 0 || index >= size()).

In your code, both your items will be removed in your while-loop. When your third loop starts, that’s when your code fails.

Read full topic

item.title: IndexOutOfBoundsException?
item.dc:creator: @sp11k3t3ht3rd sp11k3t3ht3rd
item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

How is this possible?

[code=java5] //if the ammount of ore the player has is greater than or equal to the ammount for the contract
if(j >= Player.numOfOre) {

            int oresRemoved = 0;
            
            System.out.println(Player.inventory);
            System.out.println(Player.inventory.size());

            for(int i = 0; i < Player.inventory.size(); i++) {
                
                if(Player.inventory.get(i).equals(Player.ore) && oresRemoved <= Player.numOfOre) {
                    
                    while (Player.inventory.get(i).equals(Player.ore) && oresRemoved < Player.numOfOre) {
                        
                        Player.inventory.remove(i);
                        oresRemoved++;
                        
                    }
                    
                }
                
            }[/code]

Heres an example of it running:

[code]run:

The Punished

The Gods have punished you. For what, you do not know. However, you do know that you are stuck in this place. Wherever this place is. You know not the name of the place, the name of this world, or even your own name. You have but one quest: Discover your path, and answer the questions left unanswered by the Gods, For a great story is about to unfold.
Pickaxe
-------------LOADED----------------
Inventory: [Gold, Gold]
Pickaxes (Names): Pickaxe,
Pickaxes (Durs): 760,
Gold: 0
HasContract: true
Contract Company: Black Orc
Ore for Contract: Gold
Number of Ore for Contract: 2
Max Weight: 300
Weight: 240
Reputation: 0

|---------------------------------|

Options: Descriptions:
mine Go to the mine
shop Go to the shop
bank Go to the bank
save Save your game
contract Get a contract
forest Go to the forest
dungeon Go to the dungeon
quit Exit the game.
---------------------------------

Enter your choice:
contract

You have a contract already!
[Gold, Gold]
2
Exception in thread “main” java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException: Index: 0, Size: 0
at java.util.ArrayList.rangeCheck(ArrayList.java:604)
at java.util.ArrayList.get(ArrayList.java:382)
at ContractSystem.getContract(ContractSystem.java:125)
at Main.start(Main.java:122)
at Main.main(Main.java:46)
Java Result: 1
BUILD SUCCESSFUL (total time: 8 seconds)[/code]

It’s saying that the array I’m trying to index has a size of 0 but right before that I print out that the array I’m indexing has a size of 2? The error isn’t even on the line where I try to remove the item, its on the line with the while loop. Can someone explain what is happening?

Read full topic
